text.p: Pinault-Printemps-Redoute said it did not expect a pickup in the economy during the second half of 1996 and cautioned that its full-year profit growth could not be extrapolated from the 65.5 percent jump in first-half profit.
"The management does not expect a significant improvement in the economic environment in the second half of the year," the retail conglomerate said in a statement.
"Given the second half's heavy contribution to the annual results, the rise in net attributable profit seen in the first half cannot be extrapolated for the full year," it said.
It said it would pursue productivity gains in all areas.

Pinault-Printemps' net attributable profit climbed to 748 million francs in the first half of 1996 from 452 million, helped by lower interest rates that reduced its financial expense and fewer exceptional charges in the 1996 first half.
First-half sales grew 1.5 percent to 37.75 billion francs, or a pro forma rise of 0.8 percent.
The company said sales for the first eight months were up one percent on a like-for-like basis.
